questions.text: Androgen hormones are secreted from which of the following gland/s?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Androgens are a group of steroid hormones that play a role in male traits and reproductive activity. While testes are the primary source, androgens are also produced in other glands:

  • Testes (Option A):Primary source in males; secrete testosterone, the main androgen.
  • Ovaries (Option B):Produce small amounts of androgens like androstenedione and testosterone, important for estrogen synthesis.
  • Adrenal cortex (Option C):Produces dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA) and androstenedione, which are weak androgens present in both sexes.

questions.text: Which of the following substances facilitates the delivery of a fetus?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Oxytocin stimulates uterine contractions during labor. It is released from the posterior pituitary gland and acts on the uterine muscles to initiate and strengthen contractions, thus facilitating the delivery of the fetus. (Option A)
  • Relaxin is a hormone produced by the ovaries and placenta during pregnancy. It loosens the ligaments of the pubic symphysis and softens the cervix, facilitating delivery of the fetus. (Option B)
  • High levels of estrogen increase the sensitivity of the uterus to oxytocin and prostaglandins, enhancing uterine contractions. Estrogen also promotes the formation of oxytocin receptors on the uterine muscles. (Option C)
  • Prostaglandins are also substances that help in the facilitation of delivery via cervical ripening and uterine contractions.

choices.text: Inhibit the development of male secondary sexual characteristics
Development of the testis in the embryo
Increase secretion for male sex differentiation
Responsible for the development of Mullerian duct

questions.text: Which of the following is a function of the sex-determining region on the Y chromosome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Sex-determining region is a gene (SRY gene) present on the short arm of the Y chromosome.
  • SRY is a DNA-binding regulatory protein. It causes transcription of genes necessary for testicular differentiation, including Mullerian inhibitory substance,s which inhibit the growth of the Mullerian duct from which female sex organs develop.
  • SRY promotes the development of testes, which produce androgens like testosterone that lead to the development of male secondary sexual characteristics. It does not inhibit male secondary sex characteristics.
  • The SRY gene does not directly produce hormones for male sex differentiation.

choices.text: It is an inactivated X chromosome found in somatic cell nuclei in males
It provides direction for cell division
Formed by the inactivation of the Y chromosome in males
It is an inactivated X chromosome present in somatic cell nuclei in females

questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Barr body is the condensed, inactivated X chromosome found in the nuclei of somatic cells of genetic females (XX).
  • It is a mechanism of dosage compensation, ensuring that females, like males (XY), only have one functional X chromosome.
  • This inactivation happens randomly in early embryonic life, and once an X is inactivated in a cell, all daughter cells will have the same X chromosome inactivated.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

It is an inactivated X chromosome found in somatic cell nuclei in males (Option A):
Males typically have only one X chromosome, so there is no extra X to inactivate, and hence, no Barr body is formed.

It provides direction for cell division (Option B):
The Barr body has no role in directing or regulating cell division. This function is handled by the centrosome and various regulatory proteins.

Formed by the inactivation of the Y chromosome in males (Option C):
The Y chromosome is not inactivated in males. Barr bodies are formed by the inactivation of an X chromosome, not the Y.

questions.text: Which of the following organs does not develop from the Mullerian duct in females?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The ovary develops from the genital ridges if the SRY gene is absent due to the absence of the Y chromosome. It develops from the medulla in the embryonic gonads.
  • Absence of mullerian inhibiting substance (MIS) in females will grow the Mullerian duct in females.
    • From the Mullerian duct, organs developed in females are:
    • Fallopian tubes
    • Uterus
    • Cervix
    • Upper part of the vagina
  • The external female genitalia develops from the genital tubercle, urogenital fold, and labioscrotal swellings.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Uterine tube (Option B):
Develops from the cranial unfused portion of the Müllerian duct.

Uterus (Option C):
Formed by the fusion of the caudal portions of the Müllerian ducts.

Cervix (Option D):
Also arises from the fused caudal part of the Müllerian ducts.

questions.text: During the development of the genital organs, which organ develops from the marked area?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows the structure from which the external genital organs in females and males develop. The marked structure is a genital swelling.

External genital organs are developed under the influence of DHT in males, and in females, it is due to estrogen and the absence of androgen.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy was diagnosed with a genetic disorder. On genetic mapping, he has 44+X0 chromosomal patterns. It is due to nondisjunction during cell division. What could be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The karyotype 44 + X0 indicates a total of 45 chromosomes, with only one X chromosome and no Y chromosome - this is the classic finding in Turner syndrome (45,X0).

Turner syndrome is caused by nondisjunction during meiosis, leading to monosomy X. It results in gonadal dysgenesis, where the gonads (ovaries) fail to develop properly and become streak gonads (non-functional fibrous tissue).

Turner Syndrome:

  • Karyotype: 45,X0
  • Phenotypic sex: Female
  • Main features: Short stature, webbed neck, shield chest, and streak gonads (underdeveloped gonads)
  • Cause: Nondisjunction during meiosis leading to monosomy X

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Superfemale (Option A):
Refers to 47, XXX, not 45 ,X0.

Seminiferous tubular dysgenesis (Option C):
Refers to Klinefelter syndrome (47,XXY) - a male with small testes and infertility. Not related to X0.

None of the above (Option D):
Incorrect, since gonadal dysgenesis fits the described karyotype.

choices.text: Female genotype but male external genitals

questions.text: A 23-year-old person was diagnosed with true hermaphroditism. Which among the following is not a feature of it?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

True hermaphroditism, now called Ovotesticular Disorder of Sex Development (DSD), is a rare condition where an individual has both ovarian and testicular tissue. This can occur as:

  • One ovary and one testis
  • A combined ovotestis
  • Or bilateral ovotestes

A female genotype (46,XX) with fully male external genitalia would not typically occur in true hermaphroditism because:

  • Individuals with 46,XXin true hermaphroditism do not produce enough androgens (like testosterone) from the testicular tissue to fully masculinize the external genitalia.
  • Therefore, the genitalia are usually ambiguous, not fully male.
  • A person with a female genotype and fully male external genitaliais more likely to have Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH) - a completely different condition where excess androgens are produced from the adrenal glands, virilizing a genetically female fetus.

Hermaphroditism means intersex or mixed pattern of female and male reproductive organs.

  • It can be
    1. True hermaphroditism
    2. Pseudohermaphroditism
  • True hermaphroditism
    • True gonadal intersex patients have both testicular tissue and ovarian tissue.
    • The patient may have XX chromosomes, XY chromosomes, or both.
    • The external genitals may appear as male, female, or ambiguous.
  • Pseudohermaphroditism

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Pattern may be 44+XX or 44+XY (Option A):
This is a feature of true hermaphroditism. Individuals with Ovotesticular Disorder of Sex Development (DSD) may have a variety of karyotypes. The most common is 46,XX, but 46,XY and mosaic forms like 46,XX/46,XY are also possible. Therefore, this is a true feature.

External genitals ambiguous (Option B):
This is also a feature of true hermaphroditism. Due to the presence of both ovarian and testicular tissue, the hormonal environment during fetal development can vary, leading to ambiguous genitalia. This is often the clinical clue leading to further investigation.

None of the above (Option D):
This is incorrect because Option C is not a feature of true hermaphroditism

questions.text: An 18-year-old male visited the doctor for sexual problems. On evaluation the doctor diagnosed him with pseudohermaphroditism. Among the following probable cause is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pseudohermaphroditism refers to a condition where the genetic (gonadal) sex and the external genitalia do not match. Specifically in male pseudohermaphroditism, the person has testes (XY karyotype) but incomplete or ambiguous male genitalia due to impaired androgen production or action.

Defective testicular development (Option A) can result in reduced testosterone production, which is necessary for proper male genital development. Incomplete masculinization can lead to pseudohermaphroditism. 5-alpha reductase deficiency (Option B)
5-alpha reductase converts testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT), which is essential for the development of external male genitalia. Deficiency results in ambiguous or female-like external genitalia despite normal testes and testosterone levels. This is a well-known cause of male pseudohermaphroditism.

Mutation in androgen receptor (Option C)leads to Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (AIS). The body is unable to respond to androgens, causing feminized or ambiguous genitalia despite normal or elevated testosterone levels. This is another cause of male pseudohermaphroditism.

questions.text: Among the list of the following, which is not a sex chromosome abnormality?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • From the above list, Down syndrome occurs due to trisomy 21. Its features include:
    • Round face
    • Flattened nose bridge
    • Small, irregular teeth
    • Short stature
    • Heart defects
    • Mental retardation
  • In individuals with the XO chromosomal pattern (Turner syndrome)
    • The gonads are rudimentary or absent, so that female external genitalia develop.
    • Short stature
    • No sexual maturation occurs at puberty.
  • Klinefelter syndrome pattern 44+XXY
    • Poor development of testis leading to sterility
    • Normal internal and external genitalia
    • Tall and obese
    • Gynecomastia
    • Poor secondary sexual characteristics
  • Super female 44+XXX
    • Poor sexual development
    • Scanty menstruation
    • Mental retardation
    • High plasma gonadotropins and estradiol

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Klinefelter syndrome (Option B):
Caused by the presence of an extra X chromosome in a male (47,XXY). This is a sex chromosome abnormality.

Turner syndrome (Option C):
Caused by the complete or partial absence of one X chromosome in a female (45,X0). This is a sex chromosome abnormality.

Superfemale (Option D):
Also known as Triple X syndrome (47,XXX), a condition involving an extra X chromosome in females. This is a sex chromosome abnormality.

questions.text: A surge in androgen secretion does not occur in which of the following phases in males?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Androgen secretion in males occurs in distinct surges at certain phases of life, mainly driven by testicular Leydig cells in response to LH from the pituitary. These surges are not continuous and are regulated by the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis.

The prepubertal phase (typically from around age 2 to 10 in boys) is characterized by a physiologically quiescent period of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal (HPG) axis. During this time:

  • Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH)secretion from the hypothalamus is minimal.
  • As a result, LH (luteinizing hormone)and FSH (follicle-stimulating hormone) levels are very low.
  • Consequently, Leydig cellsin the testes remain inactive, and testosterone (androgens) production stays suppressed.
  • No androgen surgeoccurs during this time, and no significant sexual development

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Intrauterine (Option A):
There is a significant fetal androgen surge, especially between 8 to 24 weeks of gestation, driven by placental hCG stimulating fetal Leydig cells. This is essential for male genital development and testicular descent.

Neonatal (Option B):
A temporary postnatal androgen surge occurs during the first 1-3 months of life, often referred to as "mini-puberty." This is caused by the temporary reactivation of the HPG axis and plays a role in early brain masculinization and testicular growth.

Adolescence (Option D):
Puberty triggers a strong and sustained androgen surge due to reactivation of the HPG axis. Increased GnRH → LH → testosterone leads to development of secondary sexual characteristics, growth spurts, and fertility.

questions.text:
Identify the sequence of development at the time of puberty in females
1. Pubarche
2. Menarche
3. Thelarche
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The correct sequence of pubertal development in females follows a predictable pattern regulated by the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis. The normal order is:

  1. Thelarche (3)- development of breast buds
  2. Pubarche (1)- appearance of pubic and axillary hair
  3. Menarche (2)- onset of menstruation

This sequence is referred to as the Tanner stages of sexual development and occurs as follows

Step-by-step:

  • Thelarche (3):
    First visible sign of puberty in girls, typically occurring around age 8-13. It marks the beginning of breast development due to rising estrogen
  • Pubarche (1):
    Follows thelarche and is driven by increased adrenal androgens(adrenarche), resulting in the growth of pubic and axillary hair.
  • Menarche (2):
    Usually occurs about 2 years after thelarche, indicating the maturation of the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis. It marks the start of ovulatory cycles and is a late event in puberty.

choices.text: Leptin is a hormone producing hunger
A girl with anorexia nervosa has decreased in level of leptin hormone
Leptin treatment can induce precocious puberty

questions.text: In the following statements not true about leptin is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Leptin is a hormone primarily produced by adipose (fat) tissue and plays a key role in regulating energy balance, appetite, and reproductive function.

Leptin is not a hormone that produces hunger - rather, it does the opposite.
Leptin acts on the hypothalamus to:

  • Suppress appetite
  • Increase energy expenditure

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

A girl with anorexia nervosa has decreased in level of leptin hormone (Option B):
Correct. In anorexia nervosa, due to low body fat, leptin levels are markedly reduced, contributing to amenorrhea and delayed puberty.

Leptin deficiency produces infertility (Option C):
Correct. Leptin is essential for normal reproductive function. Low or absent leptin (as in starvation or congenital deficiency) can lead to hypogonadotropic hypogonadism and infertility.

Leptin treatment can induce precocious puberty (Option D):
Correct. In leptin-deficient individuals, recombinant leptin therapy can activate the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis, leading to early onset of puberty.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl has developed secondary sexual characteristics. Her parents along with her visited the doctor. The doctor diagnosed her with precocious pseudopuberty From the following list, what could not be the cause of it?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The girl is diagnosed with precocious pseudopuberty, which refers to early development of secondary sexual characteristics without activation of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal (HPG) axis. In other words, the gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) is not elevated, and the puberty is being driven by peripheral (non-central)sources of sex steroids.

Disorders involving the posterior hypothalamus are not responsible for precocious pseudopuberty.

  • True (central) precocious puberty is associated with early activation of the HPG axis, typically involving the anterior hypothalamus, especially the GnRH-secreting neuronsin the preoptic area.
  • The posterior hypothalamusis primarily involved in autonomic functions and the release of vasopressin and oxytocin, not reproductive hormones.
  • Hence, disorders of the posterior hypothalamus do not cause precocious puberty, central or pseudopuberty.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Congenital virilizing adrenal hyperplasia (Option A):
Correct cause of precocious pseudopuberty. Due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency, there is excess androgen production from the adrenal glands, causing early development of pubic hair, breast enlargement, or clitoromegaly without HPG axis activation.

Leydig cell tumor of testis (Option B):
Correct cause. A testosterone-secreting tumor, even in females (rare), can lead to androgen excess and secondary sexual characteristics independent of central GnRH signaling.

Estrogen-secreting tumor in females (Option D):
Correct cause. Such tumors (like granulosa cell tumors) produce estrogen, which can lead to breast development and menstrual bleeding in girls, again without central axis activation.
